items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹616 â€” November 1, 2023 | Read on the web

<browser-window>: A Web Component to Create Pretend Browser Windows on the Web â€” Initially built to use within a slide deck (for this talk), browser-window is a lightweight themed zero-dependency web component wrapper to emulate a Safari-like browser window within a Web page. The page full of demos might give you some ideas for itsÂ use.

Zach Leatherman

Reality Check #1: Building Out a Furniture Site fromÂ Dribbble â€” This is a fun new experimental blog series where a visually stunning design is taken from Dribbble and then recreated by a professional Web developer to see how well it might function in practice. This first one is for a furnitureÂ site.

Andy Bell

Free Course: Land a Software Engineering Role â€” Jerome Hardaway has helps over 300 folks get a software development job â€” now he shares his advice in this video course â€” featuring resume tips, networking advice, how to optimize your GitHub profile for technical scrutiny, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Answering Common Questions About Interpreting Page SpeedÂ Reports â€” This post takes a closer look at how various performance tools both audit and report on various performance metrics (such as core web vitals), and then answers some common questions that arise from running suchÂ audits.

Geoff Graham

You're Gonna Need A Bigger Browser â€” Yes, browsers are hugely load-bearing in the webâ€™s architecture, and Robin notes they havenâ€™t really changed all that much. As such this post questions some aspects that seem worthy candidates for change to best serve the user goingÂ forward.

Robin Berjon

WebKit Features in Safari 17.1 â€” Hereâ€™s a rundown of whatâ€™s new. Oh, and 17.2 is already inÂ beta.

WebKit

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • â­ï¸ Yikes. None of the 100 most-visited websites globally uses HTML in full conformance with the HTML spec, though a few get very close.

  • The first ever State of React survey is now live and invites you to both test your React knowledge and share your thoughts on the React ecosystem.

  • Google's journey to mobile-first indexing is now complete.

  • Mozilla shares some details on how improvements have been made to the speed of Firefox this year.

  • In other Mozilla news, folks using Debian-based Linux distros are now being provided with Firefox Nightly .deb packages.

  • Automattic's WooCommerce is rebranding as just 'Woo'.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

The New CSS Math: rem() and mod() â€” Runs through the basics of these two new math functions and highlights some use cases. Dan notes that â€œthe nuance in how they work is not always clear from the startâ€ â€” so this quick overview should proveÂ handy.

Dan Wilson

â–¶Â Â Your Website Does Not Need JavaScript â€” An hour long talk in which Amy builds a completely static website â€” using a collection of HTML and CSS files with no tracking, no scripting, no servers, and no third-partyÂ resources.

Amy Kapernick

'Letâ€™s Reinvent the Wheel' â€” Musing on how we approach designing the web, highlighting some pain points with current methods, issues with design tools, and what role CSS can play in creating ourÂ sites.

Vasilis van Gemert

Naming Variables in CSS â€” Some conventions that you may want to consider when it comes to naming your CSSÂ variables.

Jonathan Dallas

Stick to Your True Love and Work #LikeABosch â€” You're the perfect link between code & car? Then youâ€™re perfect for us. Show your skills & join our team. LearnÂ more.

Bosch sponsor

Exit Animations â€” Animating an element as it leaves the DOM isnâ€™t something thatâ€™s particularly straightforward. Here Chris shares some options, before commenting that he hopes something like â€œ@exit-style or @exiting-style or @outgoing-style or ::outgoingâ€ lands in CSSÂ eventually.

Chris Coyier

How Blogging Platform Bear Does Analytics with CSS â€” Instead of using server logs this â€œslightly boutiqueâ€ analytics system triggers a read with a body:hover CSSÂ declaration.

Herman Martinus

Making Music with Google Sheets and Web MIDI API â€” A fun curio this â€”Â with the help of Web MIDI API, we can use Google Sheets as a musicÂ sequencer.

Asep Bagja

Passkeys: A No-Frills Explainer on the Future of Password-Less Authentication
Neal Fennimore

The UK Online Safety Bill Becomes Law, What Does It Mean?
Jenny List

â–¶Â Â Why Passkeys are the Future
Siegfried, deploy!

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Docusaurus 3.0: The Elegant Static Site Generator â€” Docusaurus is a popular React-powered tool aimed at building documentation sites in particular, though it can handle more general sites too. Folks like Supabase, Redux and Temporal use it for their doc sites. v3 features an upgrade to MDX v3, React 18, Mermaid v10, and essentially modernizesÂ everything.

SÃ©bastien Lorber

Tiny Helpers: Online Tools for Web Developers â€” We first featured this now sizeable collection of single-purpose online tools around three years ago, and it has since grown to over 500 resources. It has plenty of tools aimed at developers of all types â€”Â think things like color management, favicon generators, accessibility tools, and more.

Stefan Judis

Nightwind: Automatic Dark Mode for TailwindÂ Sites â€” An innovative and customizable Tailwind plugin that takes your current color choices into consideration when constructing a dark mode theme for your site. Try it out directly on theÂ page.

Nightwind

TailwindMate: Convert CSS Colors to and from Tailwind Format â€” Enter any CSS color (RGBA, HSLA, hex) and this tool will convert the color to the closest Tailwind named equivalent. You can also switch to â€œfrom Tailwindâ€ mode.

Jaleel Bennett

SiriWave: The Apple Siri Waveform Replicated in Pure JS â€” If you need an effect that implies sound is playing or being recorded, perhaps.

Flavio Maria De Stefano

FormsLab: An Open-Source Form Builder Toolkit for Creating Surveys, Polls, and More

Konrad Ryczko

A beautiful coming together of two of the oldest HTML elements to create somethingÂ new.

Una Kravets (Chrome Developers)

Itâ€™s not Adobe Illustrator yet, but thereâ€™s plenty to enjoy and you can export your creations as SVGs for yourÂ projects.

ImageKit | Video CDN sponsor

â–¶Â Â When 100 Developers Reproduce the Same Web Layout â€” A popular web design YouTuber asked folks on his Discord to reproduce a â€˜cardâ€™ layout however they wished. In this video, he analyzes the approaches taken which mostly break down between using grids and flexbox â€“Â though one plucky individual went with tables! (16Â minutes.)

Kevin Powell

An Introduction to Web Sustainability â€” What can designers and developers do to build a more sustainable web? Michelle explores the environmental impacts of web tech and looks at how to build greenerÂ sites.

Michelle Barker

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Chrome 117 has introduced text-wrap: pretty â€“ a new setting for the text-wrap property that handles typographic widows andÂ orphans.

  • ğŸ’ What Does Happily Ever After Look Like? is a beautiful piece of modern web design (and a cool data-led look at romance novel book coversÂ too).

  • Ricky Onsman has shared a thorough list of newsletters and blogs focused on digital accessibility.

  • We've mentioned the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines a lot, as WCAG 2.2 came out recently. If you want to get up to speed, Geoff Graham has a roundup of WCAG 2.2 explainers.

  • Safari Technology Preview 181 landed just after we sent last week's issue. It adds support for content-visibility.

The Three Cs: ğŸ¤Â Concatenate, ğŸ—œï¸Â Compress, ğŸ—³ï¸Â Cache â€” When serving and storing files on the web, Harry notes that there are a number of different things we need to take into consideration in order to balance ergonomics, performance, and effectiveness. This meaty post breaks these processes down into three: concatenating files on the server, compressing them over the network, and caching them at the otherÂ end.

Using ChatGPT for 'Smart Truncation' in Responsive Design? â€” Weâ€™re not saying this is a great approach, but the idea of â€˜responsive contentâ€™ (where the length of written content is adjusted to fit the viewing environment) is certainlyÂ intriguing.
